A very nice mix of MotherLoad and Spelunky. Sometimes it's a bit boring to mine for minerals, but the game constantly delivers new upgrades, enemies and offers a change in scenery (3 huge different unerground locations plus a lot of caves). Overall, a good way to spend 2-3 evenings.

Put in a blender Terraria, Mr Driller, Metroid and Megaman X, mix them and Steamworld Dig appears. Previously released on the Nintendo 3DS, the PC version enhances the audio-visual features of a game that was already quite remarkable.

PROS:

- Addictive (The digging and find resources and skills to level up mechanic will keep you playing non-stop until the end of the adventure)
- Acquisition of skills that make the adventure more fun as you progress (some of them quite ingenious and useful).
- Accurate and very responsive controls (calling out all those titles at the beginning of the review, you couldn't expect less).
- Charming characters and enemies design.
- The story is simple but engaging (the interest to know the mystery hidden underground is maintained at all times).
- If you are an achivement hunter, these would ensure you a second playthrough to get them all.

CONS:

- No real replayability (It lacks an New Game+ mode or something similar)
- The music can get repetitive at times.
- No quick save, you must return to the surface to generate a checkpoint-save.

If you like Metroid-Vania style games with a twist of western and a disappearing blocks mechanic (through digging) this game will grant you a good 6-12 hours of play (in my case it was 18). Addiction guaranteed.

My score: 8/10

Note: Played it on GNU / Linux (Ubuntu 14.04 LTS - 32 bits)

Steamworld Dig is a cross between a Metroid-vania and a Dungeon Crawler. Its focus, however, is the mining experience, rather than the combat. And it's works surprisingly well! You use your collected resources to upgrade your equipment, which makes traversing the map easier, as well as being able to mine deeper and deeper.

I'll say that I have not played the 3DS version, but I wouldn't have noticed that this was a mobile port. Everything is very fluid and it just works perfectly overall, unlike many mobile ports we see on Steam.


Presentation
It's a very good and clean looking game, in my opinion. Everything looks polished, is what I'd say. It gives off a good Steampunk vibe, and the character designs have a unique cartoon style as well.
It has solid lighting effects as well, that look nice and also provide a good mechanic for you to know when it's needed to go back to the surface.
There isn't much else to say, really. It looks great! And it's functional, as I've never had a problem with the backgrounds, or anything at all...

The music was a pleasant surprise too! The soundtrack is only 15 minutes long, but its purpose was achieved: atmosphere, rather than getting a melody stuck in your head. And I have absolutely no problem with that.
It uses a Blues-like vibe, with a more metallic texture, if you will, with a few Western whistles... you get the drill (eh). I actually reminded me of Torchlight or Diablo's music! Especially Tristram Village, only less dark. I really enjoyed the music.

One complaint I have is with the voices... Speaking gibberish isn't a problem for me, but it got really annoying at times, with some vendors. When you're speaking to the shopkeepers, they describe the item you're looking at every time... Since they're not really saying anything very useful, it seems like a cacophony of sounds... But that only happens when you're upgrading in the town, so it's not too bad.


So, onto the game's Structure, then.
You do virtually the same thing 3 times. And while I don't quite understand how it does it, it works! The game has 3 main sections. Each section has a certain visual theme (and some new enemies), and features 3 optional and 3 mandatory dungeons" (perhaps it's the wrong word

Three areas and a boss fight at the end will be fun, but not challenging. This is not Spelunky and it doesn't want to be. The biggest pros are the art style and the price, which for me was 2 euros. It's not worth more than that. No co-op and no replay value are the biggest cons.\n\nIf it's on sale at 80% off I'd recommend it to anyone. It's not worth it at full price.

reviewText:
SteamWorld Dig is like  a mishmash of Dig Dug, Boulderdash and Bomberman mixed with some light action platforming. The art style suits the gamer very well, and the controls just work, i found it to be very responsive.

Gameplay wise you have a vast arsenal of things at your disposal, you start off with basic variants, and then through mining different forms of crystals, gems and matter gain gold by selling them at the hub town. You then use the gold for better upgrades, which will make your journey a lot easier.

Like Dig Dug or Boulderdash you start at the top of the map and work your way down, along the way you will encounter a bunch of doors that will have new skills to unlock and secret rooms with loot for you to sell. And of course the game wouldn't be much fun without enemies, which there is a small variety of, and they will do their best to stop you and your mission.

Dying will make you loose all you inventory and respawns have a price, but like Dark Souls you can claim your inventory back if you find the place where you died, there will be a small loot bag with the items in it.

Took me around 6 hours to finish, you can do it way faster if you are good enough. There is even a speedrun achievement for finishing it in 2 hours or something like that.

reviewText:
SteamWorld Dig is a really clever and unique 2d platformer. Sort of a Minecraft meets Metroidvania. With steampunk robots in a Wild West setting. I don't remember why I grabbed this one. But I'm really glad I did.

You play as a robot who's uncle has sent for you to come to his mine in the town he lives in. When you get there, you fall into a hole and meet a girl-robot in the mine who shows you to your uncle's dead (deactivated?) corpse (or junk pile, not sure if robots have a corpse). Well now, you own the mine and your uncles mining pick. Welcome to Steamworld, population of 3.

So the basic thing is, you have a pick. You go down into the mine and mine around, looking for ore to take back to the surface and sell. Every x dollars worth of ore you bring up, you get the option to buy an upgrade from the nearby shop. There are many different types of ore you bring up, all worth differing amounts. There are also various enemies, trapped in the rock or running in tiny caverns. You can stay in the mine as long as you want, but you do have a light that slowly runs out, causing the illumination to get dimmer and dimmer until it evertually is gone. When this happens, you can barely see and definately cant see the ore you are looking for. Upgrades are things like stronger picks, longer light, stronger armor, more inventory slots and so on. There are also ladders and lamps, which can be purchased for cheap and placed in the mine but not picked up again, once they're there, they're there.  You can carry up to 4 lamps and 5 ladders, (in the beginning anyway), but wasting them sucks even though they are cheap.

There is also a little story, and various caves your uncle hid stuff in". The caves have cool power ups

reviewText: Summary Rather enjoyable metroidvania digger. Well worth the money, well worth the time. Optional logical+action challenges for completists. End boss is tedious (as usual). Recommended for platformer/metroidvania semi-casual fans.\n\nDetails In tradition of digging games like Motherload[www.miniclip.com] (and in same broad genre like Glean[www.newgrounds.com] or Mustached driller[www.newgrounds.com] and the like), you dig down from your town, periodically returning to it to sell found minerals and upgrade yourself. On your journey down you'll encounter new environments with new enemies and obstacles. The main world contains entrances to separate small levels (like instances" in MMO) - some of them required by plot and giving you new abilities
date:
some are just optional puzzles to test your brain and nimble fingers.

In best tradition of metroidvania games you are forced to return to previously explored areas and instances to uncover more. For those struck by OCD (Obsessive Completion Disorder) - game is balanced to allow you to collect every mineral and kill every monster there is in the game - given you don't screw up royally. New skills and new enemies are placed evenly on your path to the endgame - there are no tedious or boring streaks except for the final boss.

Graphically game is excelent in its cartoonish style. Technically it's also very stable
recommended: responsive and polished overall. Although I usually turn off ingame music
hoursPlayed: here I played it through without turning music off. Sound FX design is also very good.\n\nOverall
voteText: it's a nice little digger with great polish to justify it being paid."

reviewText:
Playtime: about 5 hours your first time playing
Download size: less than 200 megabytes

Steamworld Dig is a mining game similar to the old in-browser game Motherload from X Gen studios. If you haven’t played that before, it’s worth your time to try. Some of the key differences though, are in Steamworld Dig there is a storyline, there are enemies, and there are special power-up items that you find in your mining adventure.

The game’s story is pretty simple and not particularly good or bad. You play a robot (every NPC in the game is a robot) that comes to a mining town to take over a mine left by your dead (destroyed?) uncle. The goal of the game is just to dig deeper and deeper, mining out all the precious minerals and selling them to upgrade your equipment.  On your way down you’ll discover ancient sleeping enemies, many of which behave like the enemies in the Super Mario games (most of them just run back and forth in their little sections). You take damage if you touch them, so you have to use your trusty pickaxe to hack them to death.

The game’s controls are pretty simple as well, you use the directional keys to move (the game is 2 dimensional) and a few other keys to either swing your axe or switch your weapon. You have very limited inventory space (upgradeable) to store the precious minerals that you mine so you’ll find yourself climbing back to the surface every few minutes. Unlike Motherload, you cannot fly. You climb sort of like in the Megaman X games where you do little jumps against walls. This means you can’t dig around willy nilly because if you dig too big a space, you’ll make it impossible to climb back out. Fortunately you don’t have an air/fuel limit so the only real drawback of being stuck underground for long periods is you run out of light from your torch (can be upgraded). If you get stuck, just keep digging downward and eventually you’ll find a portal back to the surface.

As you progress and sell your minerals you can buy upgrades to your pickaxe, which let you dig down deeper since the ground gets harder the farther down you are (more pickaxe swings per block dug). If this is your first playthrough, I recommend buying the upgrades as soon as you can. You can’t “skip upgrades” and save money to buy something better. For example, to buy the gold pickaxe, you need to buy the silver first, or the gold one won’t unlock. Along your way you will also find special “body parts” like running boots, a hand drill, and other equipment items that give you special abilities. The hand drill is awesome for digging, but not so great for killing enemies. I actually missed one of these upgrades (a ranged weapon) until close to the end of the game, and it was required to proceed, so the game gave me a waypoint telling me which direction to go. After the first half of the game you’ll find yourself doing a lot of digging puzzles, so it’s not a completely casual game. It can actually get frustrating near the end. Don’t worry too much about deaths though. If you die, you respawn on the surface with half the money you’re carrying being confiscated. If you followed my earlier advice and bought everything as soon as you could, you probably won’t lose too much. Just bear in mind that there is a finite amount of resources. You cannot “reset” the world, and minerals do not respawn.

Pros:
+Fun game to kill time with. There’s an autosave so you can play in small time windows if you want, but you should probably play in 30 – 45 minute intervals at least, so you don’t forget where you’ve dug for minerals. Very small download size too.
+The puzzle solving starts off easy (how to dig to a mineral patch without touching enemies or getting crushed by rocks) and becomes very challenging near the end (how to get past laser walls).

Cons:
-The game is pretty short, only about 5 hours to beat. This isn’t too big a problem, except that I didn’t acquire enough money to buy all the upgrades and items. There were a few consumable items that I never got to try (ladder, teleporter).
-There’s a chance you might quit in frustration near the end of the game when you keep dying at the same places. When you respawn, you don’t have full health, and all your water is gone (water is the fuel for your steampunk equipment). This means that after a death, you don’t just need to go all the way back to where you died, you also need to find a place to refill your health and water.

Overall, the game is a decent mix up of various game genres, and put together make a pretty good game. If you have time to kill and don’t want to get into anything too serious, give Steamworld Dig a try. You’ll need to use your brain, but most of the game up until the end is pretty easy.

reviewText: Overly simplistic gameplay with limited exploration.  Dig down, collect ore, sell ore, buy upgrades, dig some more.  By the end of the game you will have all of the upgrades and no difficulty facing the boss.  I ran through what I take to be the complete game in 6 hours with no interest in doing it again.  I guess I'm spoiled by all the other great games out there, but I expect more than one hour of entertainment per dollar spent.  SteamWorld Dig doesn't provide that return.  Skip this and buy Terraria or Minecraft or something else entirely.

reviewText:
A short, but very enjoyable little platformer.

What really stands out is the awesome music and atmosphere of a Wild West-ish Town in the apocalyptic future. I really liked the overall theme and setting.

They also did a really good job on the difficulty. I found it not too hard but also not overly easy. Could have been a bit harder, but sometimes you just want to enjoy a game without stress. This game is perfect for that.

It is a bit short, you can finish it within 5 hours if you take your time, there is even an achievement for it to do it under 2.5 hours.

I normally don't like platformers too much, but the mining aspect of the game really catched my eye and it is indeed done very niceley.

Some puzzles along the way to get new powers and more money/orbs are well balanced and I never needed a lot of tries to solve them.

If you look for a nice and comfy game for a rainy sunday afternoon, this might be right up your alley. If you can beat Super Meat Boy or Spelunky with your eyes closed, you might find this way too easy.

Overall a decent game and I think it was well worth the price I paid on the Summer Sale 2014.

reviewText: This game is easily the best game I have ever played in my life. This game's plot is incredibly in depth and well thought out. I wont spoil anything in this review, but it has an fantastic story line filled with romance and betrayal. There is a great suprise ending. All of the characters have well written back stories and have great character progression. One of the robots' stories had me literally in tears by the end of the game. Her story has inspired me to reform my shallow life. The characters in this game have more depth to them than most people I know.\n\nThe gameplay to this masterpiece is very good as well. I would say that this game might be mechanically too difficult for the average casual gamer, but for truely hardcore gamers it will challenge you and truely push you to your limits. Gamers seeking a challenging game that they can seek to master will absolutely love steamworld dig. There are many different ways one can go about trying to accomplish the main goal of the game; digging". First
recommended: is using the pickaxe to break appart blocks in order to collect resorces. This might seem like a realatively easy task
hoursPlayed: but it gets more difficult as the game goes on. Luckily there are other ways to accomplish this "digging". You can use the drill and steam punch later on in the game to quickly and efficiantly dispose of pesky blocks. This will however drain one of your important resorces; "water". Managing this "water" resorce while maintaining rapid "digging" rates is one of the most important ways to improve your effectiveness in steamworld dig. This all may sound pretty complicated and technical. Sorry to disapoint casual players
voteText: but it is. Steamworld dig has an extremely high skill floor. Masters will be delighted to find it has a very high skill ceiling as well. Because of the high skill ceiling and the indepth plot steamworld dig has very high replay value. I know I have logged hundreds of hours into this game just to experience all of the outcomes.\n\nSteamworld dig has the best graphics out of any game released so far (to my knowledge). The robots and an insane level of detail and the dirt blocks look more real than the dirt outside my house. Truely the artists that put together the visuals should be praised for their attention to detail and their ability to create 3d models that bring this game to life. I have spent hours in steamworld dig just walking around so I could full appreciate the detail and craftsmenship of the game's artists. Once

reviewText: This game is a very simple side scroller style. In my opinion very reminiscent of a Mario and Dig-Dug crossover for the 21st century. Once I started playing I could not stop! reviewText: My first play session with this game felt like two hours, but was only 0.8 by Steam's count.  After that I wrote a negative review and uninstalled the game.  But I really wanted to like this game, so I reinstalled it and stuck with it, and it turned out to be a lot of fun.  Once you get some of the movement upgrades and lamp upgrades, you can dig a lot more freely without worrying about getting yourself stuck, and you aren't constantly returning to town to refresh your lamp.  So stick with it -- it gets better.

reviewText:
Core loop:

Go underground.
Dig through rocks/dirt.
Pick up ores that fall out.
Kill/avoid monsters.
When backpack is full, teleport back to surface.
Sell ore for money.
Immediately spend all money on equipment upgrades.
Go back underground.
Repeat 30 or 40 more times.
End game.

It's not a complex game, but it's fun and has enough going for it to keep you chugging along. A fair number of secrets to uncover. Also the underground caves that shift the gameplay focus away from digging and briefly toward segments of platforming/combat/problem-solving go a long way toward staving off mining fatigue.

Short. Simple. But good. Definitely worth buying if it's currently discounted.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, I've just completed this game in about 5 hours total on lunchbreaks, and frankly, I don't see what the excited reviewers are talking about.

The game is way too short.
It's a game with 3 levels and one shop overworld area. That's it. Once you complete it, I don't see why you'd bother replaying it, there's no multiplayer or even some cool New Game + mode, although upon completing the game it teases you with a new" looking main character.

Unfortunately
date: it's also WAY too easy.\nThe enemies are laughable. Even the potentially dangerous kamikaze robots leave powerups behind
hoursPlayed: even if a kamikaze targets you
voteText: there's a 33% chance you'll just get your life back in a powerup. Come on... The rest of the enemies are basically a joke
helpfulPercent:
a nuisance at best.
The laser traps are quite deadly but aren't ever used in a way that leaves you puzzled.

That's actually the problem with the entire game
votesHelpful:
there's no real puzzle element at all.
The only "puzzling" you'll see is poking around for a tile (Zelda bombable walls style) to break and reach a secret area.

The spelunking mechanic

Anyway... My personal rating would be 5/10 as in absolutely mediocre and not really worth your money.
Not recommended."

reviewText: Normally, the idea of a digging game" puts me off entirely. Terarria bored me to tears. However
date: I got this in a humble bundle and decided to try it. I found that SteamWorld Dig is a very endearing game
recommended: and a distinct advantage it has is that platforming in your own tunnels gets increasingly rewarding and interesting as you get more upgrades. On top of that
hoursPlayed: you can dig yourself into situations that then take on a more puzzle-platformer element
voteText: like getting yourself onto a certain ledge when you only have one ladder left. Getting yourself into difficult situations is often more challenging than frustrating and I appreciate that. Additionally
helpfulPercent: the music/sound design is very enjoyable and the art style is charming.\n\nThe largest complaint I take with SteamWorld Dig is the scarcity of resources
votesTotal: that trying to scrimp the last chocomite out of an early world area when you're preparing to fight the end boss is pretty unrewarding. I feel like special areas that can only be reached with certain upgrades should have substantially more loot.\n\nOn the whole
votesFunny: SteamWorld Dig is what I might consider a hidden gem
commentsCount: so to speak. The digging itself isn't too tedious (and gets better as you go along)
column16: the platforming is rewarding
column17: the art and music direction is pleasing
column18: and the plot isn't half bad. The late game can get a little tiresome if you don't have the finesse to take out the final boss without a lot of upgrades
column19: but I don't think it would prevent many people from having a positive experience."

reviewText:
Was lulled to a deep sleep by the rhythmic sound of my pickaxe hitting rock.

Pros:

reviewText: I'm not recommending this because there's a danger you're looking at this and thinking\n\nHey
date:
that's one of those digging games"

It's not one of those digging games...

Basically
recommended: what you're looking at is a jumpy platformer which just happens to require you dig between areas - and requires you earn upgrades to do that.\n\nThe 'game' here is timed rrunning/jumping/wall jumping and the controls are - erm - not the best
hoursPlayed:
shall we say.

You character also slides on landing (you fall off a lot) and generally just doesn't have the pin sharp control you want in a platform game (all IMO of course)

The game is also pretty short and quite grindy even tho it's fairly short.

Want a digging game?  Look elsewhere (perhaps Motherload/Super Motherload)

Want a platformer with tight controls?  Loads of those out there which won't demand you grind to unlock the next level too!"

reviewText:
SteamWorld Dig is as the name implies, a game about digging... and that's pretty much all there is to it.

The game is incredibly short (I've beaten it in about 5 hours, including bonus levels that are spread around), and between the extremely repetitive, dumb enemies and the incredibly simple mechanics, there is almost no challenge involved, with the exception of the final boss, which can be mildly challenging.

There is little consequence for failure: die and you will be revived. Your lost loot will stay there so you can pick it back up and keep going. Healing and refilling your water tank which you acquire fairly early in the game are both very easy to do.

Speaking of the loot though, all you can find is different types of ore (which are only used for money) and special orbs with are used in more expensive purchases that improve your character: You can dig faster, have more health and so on. There are upgrades spreaded around here and there that WILL change your character, such as a steam-powered jump or a drill, but ultimately, even they do little to improve the game's overly simple mechanics.

The soundtrack while good enough, isn't very diverse and can get boring pretty quickly. The only good thing I can say about it is: The game's pretty, it has a nice aesthetic to it... but that's not enough for me to recommend it, unfortunately.

It probably has some value as a My first platformer" for those who never played the genre and are hoping for an easy
date: unchallenging experience or if it is on some very generous (75%+) sale
recommended: but otherwise I'd say skip it.\n\nThere are other platformers out there such as Spelunky
hoursPlayed: Guacamelee or Battleblock Theater that can offer you a more enjoyable experience
votesFunny: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
SteamWorld Dig got a fair amount of hype and praise when it released. While this is quite polished, and deserves the asking price, I found myself wanting more. Much more. It feels a *bit* more like a mobile game to me. I get that it is not, but ... Still.

It plays like a MetroidVania lite with a low amount of upgradability.

The whole package - the artwork and music and atmosphere - is fine enough, but this does not bring the level of complexity or open-worldness that is fairly standard with games like this.

It is not bad by any means, just short on features and complexity.

reviewText: Worse than a $1 Xbox Indie GameAre you one of those people who never waded into the cesspit of Xbox Indie Games to find the few gems in it? If so, you missed the only-costs-a-dollar 2009 classic Miner Dig Deep, where you dig deeper into the mine to find rare minerals so you can afford better equipment and eventually reach the bottom. SteamWorld Dig has much better art than MDD, but is otherwise inferior in every way. In this game you can walljump, which largely removes the challenge of carefully tunneling in such a way that it's actually practical to leave the mine with your haul. Combat has also been added in, and it's BAD - your mining pick has a very short reach, and the two monsters I've encountered so far are more of a nuisance than a real threat. There are also special platforming levels (where you aren't allowed to use your items such as ladders to avoid the stupid platforming) that feel really out of place.

reviewText: The first hour really isn't encouraging me to keep playing. It's a pretty game, but the mechanics design is lacking. You can only dig directly to your left, right, up, or down, and you can't dig while jumping. This means that you can easily get yourself stuck, since you have no way of building an upwards staircase, or breaking through a ledge two blocks above you.\n\nIf you're really into the wild west steampunk robot aesthetic, then you'll probably enjoy this game, but as an exploration game/digger it fails in many respects. The linear puzzle levels are where it shines, but getting between those is a slog of slowly digging downwards and avoiding the gems not in your path out of fear of getting stuck.

reviewText: This game is fantastic. Everything Super Motherload did wrong (which is more or less everything) this game did right. The pacing is great, the increase in game mechanics is nice and steady, there's always interesting new areas or obstacles to deal with as the game progresses. There's a real sense of accomplishment as you gradually upgrade your character and begin digging in ways that would certainly have trapped or killed you earlier. The plot is great, the characters are neat, and I encourage people to play this.

reviewText:
Not a bad little game.

You dig down into the ground to find ores, while trying to dodge/kill the various monsters underground. Then you return to the surface to sell the ore and buy upgrades so you can go do it again.

Very nice art style.

One problem I have with it is the fact you can't reconfigure the controls, they are set in stone.

reviewText:
This game popularly known as Rango The Game. Honestly I'd rather watch the movie than play it. I mean seriously, the voice actor for Rango isn't even Johnny Depp!!! Also, the depiction of Rango in this game makes him appear more robot-like than lizard. The gore in the game is quite graphic too, I let my child watch me while I played and when I died he ran off crying and has never been the same. When I finally finished this gruesome fps lizard-simulator, the town wasn't given anymore water..... like what the hell?? ITS NOT EVEN THE SAME ENDING AS RANGO!!!!!!!!!!

Steamworld Dig??? More like Rango Unchained....

Gameplay: Needs a more open world approach... more of a like a Skyrim to get that real Rango feel
Story: Needs more lizards and Johnny Depp voice acting
Graphics: Needs updated graphics to get anywhere in the world... more like Roblox or Battlefield 4
Engine: I have a nvidia geforce 990gtx graphics card
date: and yet I can run Battlefield 4 on ultra with ENBs enabled better than this.... savagely hardware intensive had to build a new computer just for this game\n\nThank you... can't wait for more!!!!"

reviewText:
Fun little game and very polished. It's not an incredibly long game, so pick it up on sale. After completing the game there are some definite issues that will either please hardcore gamers or seriously ♥♥♥♥ people off.

Good:
Style is pretty nice
Great music and atmosphere
Upgrades to your character come pretty quickly, there's no grinding as such
Lots of side things to do, and some of the achievements look like you have to make a serious effort.
It's not like minecraft where you can dig wherever you want (pretty much). You need to plan routes or you can easily become stuck. You can't jump & mine simultaneously.

Bad:
Walljumping feels weird sometimes, but this is a problem with lots of games with wall jumping

Some deaths can be rage inducing. Initially I had take teleporters here" but don't because...

There is ZERO leeway on the number of orbs available in relation to what needs to be spent on upgrases. Spend any on teleporters? Sorry you're locked out of late game upgrades. Also I'm pretty sure there's not enough money to get through unless you play a perfect game. If you want to do achievements then this forces a second unnecessary playthrough.

Digging can get a bit tedious unless you keep up to date on your pick and drill.

Combat is kinda annoying. Wish there was an alternative to hitting something with your pick and waiting for it to path back. Dynamite isn't always a good choice.

I didn't know you could charge the fist until right at the end of the game. I don't know if it's mentioned in a tooltip
hoursPlayed:
you can charge it to make it go farther.

The sleeping trilobite achievements are BS and once again you're screwed if any of them wake up. Which they will in Vectron because you won't have the drill power to get them before they do. Unless you knew beforehand about it.

Overall it isn't a game I would've paid full price for
voteText: but it was a fun time waster. On the one hand I like that the achievements aren't just "you loaded the game
votesHelpful: but on the other hand I don't think it's fair to force players through replaying a not very replayable game to get achievements that you have to plan for perfectly. For example
votesTotal: sequence breaker requires you to know about the story's events beforehand
votesFunny: and then abuse game mechanics to achieve since you can't collect the needed upgrades to access the specific areas. Is this fair? I don't know. It feels like lazy design instead of adding more content."

reviewText:
Mechanically solid 2D platformer, but extremely light on interesting mechanics.

You're a miner digging ever deeper (for no really good reason), finding more gems to convert to gold to buy mining equipment upgrades to dig deeper to find more gems...you get the idea. This could be ok, but the mining itself is very straightforward in two dimensions and there's little variation in what you do. Same with the upgrades, they are almost all just slight numerical increases in the pickaxe / drill / health / steam power you have.

The aesthetic is nice, with a good art style and music. Controls are very responsive and your mobility gets pretty good towards the end of the game as you unlock more metroid-like powers.

Ultimately though, not enough here to keep this interesting past a few hours. If you want to gather resources and work through the logistics of mining, Minecraft is where you should be spending your time.

reviewText: I would say that the Metroid influence here is very clear except that this game has very limited replay value. In general it takes around 6-7 hours to play through as a casual pace and frankly I was disapointed that it didn't progress into a more open ended game. This almost reminds me of Mr Driller, but with some character development. At it's normal price of £6.99 I wouldn't recommend it, but when it is on offer for less than £3 I would say it is worth a look if you want to enjoy a limited but well polished game with a lot of personality.

I loved the old Motherload. SteamWorld Dig has a lot of similarities to it and that is something, that makes it really great. So a fast review would be: If you liked Motherload, you probably gonna love SteamWorld Dig too.

The longer review goes like this:
SteamWorld Dig is a very nicely made Platformer. I don't like normal Platformers that much, but this one instantly pulled me in. It has very nice graphics and a cool style. And the mining is really addicting. May it seem pretty brainless to some people? Of course. But as said: It has the Motherload-effect. Just one more round of digging."

The worst part of it
date: is that the game is pretty short. I would have loved to dig even deeper. But I rather have a good game
recommended: that is very entertaining for a short time
hoursPlayed: than a boring game
voteText: that keeps on forever.\n\nAll in all: This game is worth it's money. And if you can grab it in a sale at some point: Don't hesitate!"

reviewText: SteamWorld Dig is a game that I've wanted for a very long time. I've seen it on the eShop, YouTube, Steam, and now that  I own it, it's clear I wanted it for a good reason.\nSteamWorld Dig is a game where you inherit a mine after your uncle passes away. It is your responsibilty to feed Tumbleton the minerals it needs to improve things. In my opinion, it's one of the best ideas for a game I've ever seen. You have a mine, you mine the mine, you sell the minerals, and you upgrade everything. It's like a tycoon, except more interesting. The deeper down you get, the more treacherous the mine becomes. With strange creatures and environments, hours of fun can be had. I bought the game yesterday, and installed it today, and almost played 2 hours straight. It's absolutely wonderful fun. If you get the chance, you HAVE to add this to your collection. You wont regret it.

You have a mine, you mine the mine, you sell the minerals, and you upgrade everything. It's like a tycoon, except more interesting. The deeper down you get, the more treacherous the mine becomes. With strange creatures and environments, hours of fun can be had. I bought the game yesterday, and installed it today, and almost played 2 hours straight. It's absolutely wonderful fun. If you get the chance, you HAVE to add this to your collection. You wont regret it.

reviewText: I only just started playing it, and it's pretty good so far. Really nice art style, good gameplay, and an interesting enough story for a game about robots living in a mining town. However, for a platforming game, the platforming is pretty messed up. I've frequently found myself trapped because I dug a strangely shaped tunnel and cant get back out of it. This really bugs me, since I've now become discouraged from digging freely, since I have the constant worry that I may trap myself. The fact that I am nervous about doing one of the main aspects of the game is poor design in my opinion. I can't attest to the game in the long run, since I only just started, but I would atleast give it a 7/10 so far.

reviewText:
A very mixed bag with this game. It cannot decide what it wants to be. Does it want to be super mario with the double jump and a head boss at the end? Does it want to be a game where you just explore and look for loot? The start of the game was great. Look for loot and get a better drill and other powers ups.  No time limit just explore to your hearts content.

Great idea. Build up a town using loot to attract others. However for whatever reason they got bored with that idea and switched over to a head boss. Where you need to dodge laser beams, tons of bad guys and my favorite blocks that re appear after 2 seconds. Those never get old. Oh boy. Not only do you have to do this 3 times it gets harder after each wave. Great.  I feel like this game was designed by 2 different mind sets. One wanted it to be about exploring the other wanted a Mario Clone. Who doesnt love Mario right?

The game looks and reminds me a lot like Platformines. However where that game knew what it was exactly. This game tries to straddle both lines and doesnt do a very good job at either. I recommend it with some caveats. Get the game cheap because its not a long game. Took me around 5 hours to get to the head boss. I did not finish the game as I got mad at the stupid end boss. Tried 3 times and called it a wrap. I Watched the ending on youtube.

I wish they would have another game like this and leave out the Mario stuff and make the game what it should be exploring and finding stuff. I give it 6/10.

reviewText:
If you're like me and you enjoy action platformer games with RPG elements (I am of course talking about the Metroid/Castlevania/Megaman genre), you will probably love this game.

In the same vein as Dig Dug (I couldn't help using the pun!), SteamWorld Dig is primarily a digging game, featuring a robotic miner that mysteriously obtains the deed to a derelict mine. As you search the seemingly endless depths of the mine you collect resources, purchase power ups and retrofit your robot body with new upgrades, better weapons and digging equipment in order to reach even further into the darkness. All the while you must contend with environmental hazards, avoid falling down wells, combat the creatures the live underground and figure out how to reach ancient treasures in underground ruins.

Additionally, you also have to contend with running out of light, water and inventory space - giving the game a slight survivalist undertone. Of course, you can upgrade your capacity to hold these resources through retrofits and upgrades in town.

The story is great, the music and art is great, the controls are superb (I used an old Logitech Dual Shock controller with no problem) and the abilities and upgrades, if you take the time to grind for them, are mighty indeed!


My only 2 gripes about the game are:

1) Some of the dialogue" noise that the robot NPCs in town make. Some of them were particularly grating on the ears.

2) The game left me wanting more! Despite taking my time and grinding for all the upgrades
date: I finished the game in under 10 hours. However
recommended: considering I didn't pay much (less than $5 dollars) and considering it was a greenlight game
hoursPlayed: I really can't gripe
voteText:
especially considering the replayability of the game and the cool achievement goals.


What more can I say!? Treat yourself to SteamWorld Dig immediately!
"

reviewText:
SteamWorld Dig isn't bad, but it really just made me want to play Spelunky.  If you can get it cheap, it's worth a play through if you like these type of games, but overall I can't recommend it as a buy.

This game is not trite or contrived at all.  It's quite the opposite...it's fresh and interesting, and it's authentic and well-done.  It simply isn't as fun as it could or should be, and in the end is not a particularly satisfying play.  On one hand, I beat it as fast as I could so I could get it over with, but on the other hand, it was interesting enough to make me want to finish.

SteamWorld is a cute little game, and the story is fine, but too much of the game is either repetitive or simply not fun.  The only non-repetitive part is using the new tech you acquire as you progress, and certainly the new tech is pretty fun to use.  But the game is so short, you are acquiring the new tech about every 30 minutes or so, in which time the novelty from the previous acquisition has not yet worn off.  More simply put, acquiring new tech was sort of ho-hum rather than exciting.

Story and graphics
These are definitely strong points.  Along with overall atmosphere.  I got the rogue man in a strange new world feeling from it.  The townspeople are good characters and add to the feeling of authenticity.

Gameplay
Gameplay is fine, and probably is the biggest challenge, in a good way.  Getting a feel for the wall jumping takes some practice, but when you get it down, you can maneuver quite well, and it is rewarding.   Combat is pretty simple...it could be more dynamic.  Combat gets repetitive.  Also, having to climb back out of the cavern time after time gets old fast.

Upgrades, Leveling, and Resource Management
These are fun at first, but get repetitive quickly.  Finding minerals gets old fast.  It becomes a chore.  Upgrades are very linear and uninteresting (each upgrade is basically plus damage or more resource efficiency).  Upgrades would have been much more interesting if there were trees to choose from or tradeoffs (speed vs power, or different gimmicks) instead of having them be so linear.  Finding the crystal balls is exciting at first, but toward the end, they seemed to be everywhere.  Also, I found the limited lantern time to add nothing to the game...it only served to annoy when the flame ran out.

TL;DR:  SteamWorld Dig is a short game with a fresh story and environment, and certainly some fun parts, but it has too many repetitive and overly linear aspects that make it overall not particularly satisfying to play.

reviewText:
I had recently received this game as a gift for my birthday and never really gave it much thought before receiving it. Once I started the game up and the art style was very appealing so I thought maybe I will enjoy this game, however that was not the case.

(I will be going through the game so spoiler alert!)

The game started where you are this random character (Rusty) arriving at this small town to claim your uncles mine (Which apparently is just as low as you can go that there is really no mine but just dirt you can mine through). The first problem with the game is how your character claims “I am not a miner” which is one of his three lines he says throughout the game but once he gets trapped underground he knows automatically how to throw that pickaxe around with enough force to break the earth (although I will admit is just nitpicking but I feel that this line is redundant beyond belief.)

After the intro, the flow of the game until the final boss literally plays out like a pay-to-play mobile app using the typical RPG cycle of collecting, selling, and upgrading then rinse and repeat which is only just barely fun, I found myself coming back to this game but for all the wrong reasons, not because it was a fun experience or for a well written story but to actually see if the game gets better (I really wanted to like this title). Sadly though the game never got better, and because of that has no replay ability, and the only incentive it gives to play again is that it gives out a star rating of bronze, silver, or gold, so maybe a player wants to desperately get a gold rating.

the game has absolutely no story/character development throughout all the NPCs and your character, but then once you hit the final boss the game suddenly acts like it had story development the entire time and expects the player to (imply?) there was some sort of character development. Which is the main reason I am so bothered with the lack of story, I feel like you have to have one or the other, but this game fails at each spectrum, instead of giving an arcade style game you can pick up and play, or a long story driven game. You have a long boring game with no award for beating it.

The boss at the end of the game (which was a assimilate everything super computer) exclaims that you are already pretty much assimilates with all of the boss’s technology that you have upgraded yourself with. In reality this is kind of true because there are platforms that give you a new ability but there is no visual change that implies you are no longer what you were at the beginning of the game. (All that is changed is one of your arms that shows what tool you have. The final fight was disappointing as well, it was not a real challenge and did not use anything you learned to defeat it. Any player could defeat it having no upgrades and the basic pickaxe. However you would need all the upgrades to get to the end, besides the virtually worthless fist upgrade.

What bothers me afterwards is the ending as well, the area you are fighting the boss in collapses so everyone in town decides to try to find you and there is also a random forced love interest in the shop (you sell your minerals) keeper and the main character, which as I said before there was no character development so this came out of left field. And the icing on the cake is that Rusty escapes, but instead of coming back to the town where the erected a statue in his memory and adore him beyond belief and have a wife and a job he decides to skip town. So now only is he a synthetic cardboard cutout of a character he also is now a jerk.

So for anyone deciding to purchase this game only do so knowing that you are buying a game boasting it has great story and character development but had a story with less depth than a dry sidewalk and characters flatter than cardboard, which is a digging simulator. But hey at least it looks pretty...

2/10
★☆☆☆☆
F

reviewText:
I had recently received this game as a gift for my birthday and never really gave it much thought before receiving it. Once I started the game up and the art style was very appealing so I thought maybe I will enjoy this game, however that was not the case.

(I will be going through the game so spoiler alert!)

The game started where you are this random character (Rusty) arriving at this small town to claim your uncles mine (Which apparently is just as low as you can go that there is really no mine but just dirt you can mine through). The first problem with the game is how your character claims “I am not a miner” which is one of his three lines he says throughout the game but once he gets trapped underground he knows automatically how to throw that pickaxe around with enough force to break the earth (although I will admit is just nitpicking but I feel that this line is redundant beyond belief.)

After the intro, the flow of the game until the final boss literally plays out like a pay-to-play mobile app using the typical RPG cycle of collecting, selling, and upgrading then rinse and repeat which is only just barely fun, I found myself coming back to this game but for all the wrong reasons, not because it was a fun experience or for a well written story but to actually see if the game gets better (I really wanted to like this title). Sadly though the game never got better, and because of that has no replay ability, and the only incentive it gives to play again is that it gives out a star rating of bronze, silver, or gold, so maybe a player wants to desperately get a gold rating.

the game has absolutely no story/character development throughout all the NPCs and your character, but then once you hit the final boss the game suddenly acts like it had story development the entire time and expects the player to (imply?) there was some sort of character development. Which is the main reason I am so bothered with the lack of story, I feel like you have to have one or the other, but this game fails at each spectrum, instead of giving an arcade style game you can pick up and play, or a long story driven game. You have a long boring game with no award for beating it.

The boss at the end of the game (which was a assimilate everything super computer) exclaims that you are already pretty much assimilates with all of the boss’s technology that you have upgraded yourself with. In reality this is kind of true because there are platforms that give you a new ability but there is no visual change that implies you are no longer what you were at the beginning of the game. (All that is changed is one of your arms that shows what tool you have. The final fight was disappointing as well, it was not a real challenge and did not use anything you learned to defeat it. Any player could defeat it having no upgrades and the basic pickaxe. However you would need all the upgrades to get to the end, besides the virtually worthless fist upgrade.

What bothers me afterwards is the ending as well, the area you are fighting the boss in collapses so everyone in town decides to try to find you and there is also a random forced love interest in the shop (you sell your minerals) keeper and the main character, which as I said before there was no character development so this came out of left field. And the icing on the cake is that Rusty escapes, but instead of coming back to the town where the erected a statue in his memory and adore him beyond belief and have a wife and a job he decides to skip town. So now only is he a synthetic cardboard cutout of a character he also is now a jerk.

So for anyone deciding to purchase this game only do so knowing that you are buying a game boasting it has great story and character development but had a story with less depth than a dry sidewalk and characters flatter than cardboard, which is a digging simulator. But hey at least it looks pretty...

2/10
★☆☆☆☆

reviewText:
This game made the fundamental mistake that I see rather often. It attempted to create a fusion of several great games and genres, but did so without a core comprehension of what made those games good in the first place. The gameplay can be split into three aspects.

The first is the town area, where you can buy upgrades and talk to people. That's about it. To be fair, not much more can be expected out of a town area in a game with only a few hours of gameplay. But you may very well come to hate this town as you keep having to return over and over again.

The second aspect are the caves beneath the town. Have you ever played Minecraft or Terraria and thought, Man
date: I love digging through solid walls for extended periods of time!"? If so
recommended: this might be the game for you. Otherwise...\nThere are things to be found in the caves
hoursPlayed: yes. However
voteText: all of the major things you /need/ to find are thrown right into your face so you don't miss them. On top of that it's just enemies
votesTotal: the game has a brilliant way of artificially extending its length: only letting you carry three stacks of an ore at once. I don't really see any good reason for this besides forcing you to go back up to the surface sometimes. Which of course involves backtracking all the way up the shaft you've dug down up to the last warp point to the surface. Other than that occasionally interrupting the game flow (and using the word "occasionally" is being generous)
votesFunny: it's nothing but digging around looking for ores and then digging downwards to continue with the game. Oh
commentsCount: and did I mention that the better digging tools you get all have limited fuel? So you'll need to backtrack for that too. This whole major aspect of the game feels incredibly pointless and like it's designed to take way longer than it needs to.\n\nThe final aspect of the game are the special challenge caves you find along the way.  These are certainly the best part of the game
column16: but they're dragged down by the main cave. If the main cave didn't exist and the engine was truly made for a platformer with puzzle aspects rather than what it is
column17: they would likely play a lot better. The most apparent example is enemies. Combat just does not play out very well because all of your "weapons" are digging tools. I think if the entire game consisted of gameplay like in these caves and if the engine was made to reflect that then the game would certainly have a lot of potential. But as is? Eh....."

reviewText:
The game has no illusions about what it is and what it intends for you to do: dig, gather minerals and sometimes hit bugs just like you're hitting stones. An hour in and if I wasn't listening to podcasts I would be extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I just wasted that much time. Progression is slow; you have to methodically chip away at the walls and make sure that you've got some openings on the walls on the off chance you pass under some minerals that you cannot reach. You can expand your pack but you're still running back to the nearest teleporter every few minutes to drop off another load in the hopes that you can afford a decent upgrade.

The platforming is stiff and entirely reliant on finding certain upgrades rather than any actual skill: if you can't reach it, you're not meant to yet. Oh and there is some light backtracking, great.

It's just a mindless, bland little game. Lovely graphics and a cute idea but if you have any other game to play, do that instead.

reviewText: Though I enjoy the game's art design and setting, the gameplay is completely bland. You grind for minerals in order to collect upgrades. The upgrades let you grind for materials more efficiently. The monsters you fight are limited, and the fighting mechanics are subpar at best. The act of digging for minerals just isn't fun, and the only reward you get for partaking in this dull exercise is the ability to dig deeper in order to find even more minerals.
voteText: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When it comes right down to it, the game is boring.  You essentially dig into dungeons and ore and fight enemies with your pickaxe.  That's about it, it doesn't really expand the forumula, even given the additional powerups, not to mention you're holding the dig button all the time and occasionally jumping if you're avoiding something or going back to the base to sell stuff.

The biggest issue is the variation that is there, is not very engaging or interesting.  You'll gather minerals to get a better pickaxe to then gather more minerals gaining a few special moves along the way.  The enemy varation is very poor, there's few enemies and they all are bit on the floaty side.  The first ones you encounter you just hold your dig button and trap them agains the wall and the second you hit them and run away, then repeat.

I wanted to like this game, but due to it being singleplayer only, lacking depth (pun) and being incredibly repetitve, I didn't even get enjoyment out of it from a bundle, and I LOVE Terraria, it's easily one of my faves.

I'd say avoid.

reviewText:
This game was surprisingly fun. It has something for everyone. Casual players can enjoy the game and hardcore players can aim for the time, resource, and no death achievements.

This game plays like Dig-Dug and oldshool Megaman had a baby. There are various upgrades to buy, which adds fun, but there is no new game plus. Replay value is offered in the form of the previously mentioned achievements.

This game was a great break from more story intensive games where every decision alters your course. It has just enough story to make progressing interesting.

8/10

reviewText:
Plot (Engaging, but nothing too spectacular):
Rusty (if I had a nickel for every robot with that name…) inherits a mineshaft from his dead uncle but soon discovers there’s some pretty weird stuff going on down there. Mainly curiosity is the driving force behind the plot and once that curiosity is fulfilled the rest if somewhat forgettable. On top of that the game ends on a somewhat sad note (and from what I can tell, there aren’t any alternate endings).

As for the other characters they’re fairly generic and a bit annoying. You’ve got your old-geezer, rootin-tootin-Texan, rich snob, bimbo and the other fem-bot with a fairly bland personality. One particular quirk that stands out is that Rusty only talks at the beginning and end of the game. In between he’s your silent protagonist.

Gameplay (I think I’ve seen similar on a popular flash-game hosting site):
If you’re looking for another Terraria you’re going to be disappointed. While it plays borrows from the block-mining genre like Terraria, Starbound and Junk Jack it seems quite lacking in depth by comparison. Mining serves to acquire ores with which to upgrade Rusty. There’s no crafting, all you can do with the ores is sell them for upgrades to buy from the old-geezer, rootin-tootin-Texan and rich-snob. Also you can’t skip upgrades. Say you have enough for the highest tier armor, but you still have basic armor. Before you can buy the highest tier you have to buy the other armors first. Back to the mining, you can’t put blocks back which can make it difficult to reach those ores you missed if you’re not strategic about how you dig. While you can buy ladders you can only hold 5 at a time and you can’t take them back once you set them down.

Replay Value (…meh):
The game follows a linear path with a definite end rather than a sandbox type game with endless replay value. At the end you’re given an evaluation for your performance such as how long you took or how many times you died. There’s probably an achievement for getting gold on all ranks, but personally I can’t say I find the game interesting enough to try for it.

All and all I wouldn’t say it’s a bad game, but if you’re looking for something that will keep you busy long term, look elsewhere.

reviewText: Boy is this game boring. It is a real life pickaxe swinging simulator combined with a simulation of wall jumping back up hundreds of feet that you have dug to constantly go back up to the surface to sell items. I found a teleporter, but that only works for so long until you dig down so far that it becomes a real chore and a burden getting back to it, especially since if you dug around a certain way you can't jump up but sometimes you can use a steam powered jump but if you are out of water you can't use it... what a mess. I couldn't afford another personal teleporter because I didn't have any more blue orbs and they are hard to come by, so it was back to wall-jumping my way back up to the teleporter to reach town. In fact, this could have been a much better game if there was a easier way to get back to town to sell your mined ore, but there isn't. Not much to say about this one other than the fact that it’s short but sweet. The music/sound is good and the gameplay style/mechanics are like a steampunk version of Terraria set in the old west (sans the crafting, among other features).  The price isn’t bad, especially when you get it on sale, and among the many retro games available on Steam this is certainly a diamond in the rough.\n
Amazing little mining game.\n

Yet to complete the game, but I believe I have an idea of the ending just up to where I played until. Completed. General impression is pretty good. Don't know why, but I liked how you could plan the dig (awfully simple) on your way down.

PROS
1. More story as you dig deeper
I won't spoil this for you as I can only tell you that there is more stuff to get and play with as you dig deeper

2. Digging plans
You actually have to plan how you dig downwards as certain areas can regrow back. Of course, it can be solved with an infinite amount of cheap ladders. You also want areas that have water (mana) to use items such as the drill, steam punch and steam jump.

3. Teleporters
I like how you can set your save point wherever you want. I tend to put mine near the water points as you don't have water recharges close by.

CONS
1. Linear
Just dig down. It's so simple.

2. Pickaxe
Oh god... It is so tedious to dig with your pickaxe when you run out of water for the drill.

3. No tutorial
So you have to guess what the keys are or press Esc. Really ridiculous.

4. Lamps
I think there should be a use for them but I've never really needed them.

5. NPCs
Very boring. Only 5 robots? And every additional one is just a shop? You might as well put them all in one. None of them are special.

6. Enemies
Worm and robotic worm? Most of them are unique in their abilitiy but you tend to see a lot of them and you kill them all the same way... Just smack them hard...

SUGGESTION
I think there's a Japanese digger game that's similar to this. Perhaps, some competitive multiplayer might make this game even more valuable? E.g. Race to the bottom maps?

reviewText: Great Addicting Mining Game.\nYou'll definitely spend enjoyable hours.

If your looking for a 2d exploration platformer thats not too difficult, and has a medium length to it, then this would be a good choice. I completed it in around roughly 8 hours and the best way I could describe Steamworld is if Digdug and Metroid had a baby. The art style is very pleasing to the eye and I really enjoyed the music. The characters are likable and the story, while not original, isn't bad. Like I said before the game isn't very difficult, the times I died were due to my own impatience or lack of paying attention, and the only penalty for death is half your money, which is no big deal as by the end game money comes in fairly easy.\n\nThe main mechanic of the game is to explore underground and mine for precious ore while trying to discover what happened to Rusty's, the main characters, uncle. You bring the ores back to the surface and sell them to buy upgrades, that in turn allows you to reach new areas. After you get deep enough that trecking back to the surface is a chore, you discover teleport pads that take you right back to the surface, and when your done with the shops return you to where the pad is underground. There are a few pads already placed but you can buy your own and place them where you wish as well. I really enjoyed Steamworld Dig and highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys 2d platformers or exploration games.

A charming platformer/miner with RPG elements. It holds some hints of metroidal levels within its main mining focus. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

All that being said, I don't think I found the replayability resident in the game. I took away about six hours of total game time from start to finish.

The art is beautiful, the mining and movement systems entertaining, but the length of the game/urge to replay slightly lacking.

I recommend it with that one main reservation.

(Disclaimer, this is not a spoiler, although it may seem like it, there is no hinting to what the end IS.) The ending, I love ends of games due to the fact that practically anything can happen. But when I completed it, I knew what the 1 drawback to this game was, once you finished the ending... It started from the last save... THE LAST SAVE! There's no after the ending, you just get to play through the ending over and over again until you make a new save... So overall I'd give this game an 8/10... so I would recommend this game, but it's not my all time favorite...

Sorta feels like metroid or mega man X with getting the upgrades finding out how to use them best, A lot of times while playing I was reminded of Mr. Driller, although much slower paced. For a short game I like how it starts to feel more like a platformer to keep you interested and takes a really great turn near the end. The music is one of my favourite things about this game. If you've watched Joss Wedon's Firefly. you'll dig (ha!) the soundtrack to this game.

SteamWorld Dig is a fun little game that blends Metroidvania-esque ability progression with the platforming and money management of a mining game. You play a robot drawn to a dusty Western mining town, who discovers his miner uncle has died and left him a hole in the ground. Your goal: get to the bottom of it.

The game has a great visual style and I found the core mechanics engaging, if more than a little repetitive. It was fun for a playthrough. However, I don't think it's a home run game.

My first complaint is the story. The world of SteamWorld Dig is a neat one--a world where steam-powered robots are the dominant civilization, and some untold catastrophe has left humans trapped under the earth. But the driving plot of the game is thin to the point of being unsubstantial. Supposedly, you dig deeper in order to figure out just what your uncle was up to, but as a player, I didn't care a lick about that. I was digging just to dig.

A more compelling plot would have provided me with reason to care about my uncle and what he found. Since the mechanics of the game encourage an obsession with digging deeper, tying an insatiable urge to dig into the character of the uncle would have made him more sympathetic, and caused the story to resonate better with the gameplay. As it stands, I entirely ignored the plot" of the game
date: and I feel the lack of a story detracted from the experience.\n\nSecondly
recommended: SteamWorld Dig seems to me to have very little replay value. Your mileage may vary if you're inspired by achievements and the idea of speedrunning
hoursPlayed: but for me
votesHelpful: and maxed out most of my stats
votesTotal: I had no reason to play the game again. That's because the game's progression is almost entirely linear
votesFunny: with very few challenges requiring backtracking or use of your new abilities (as one might expect from a Metroidvania game). What's more
commentsCount: unless you are very bad at money management
column16: there are next to no branching options for character development in the game; you can upgrade your pickaxe and your other tools and other attributes
column17: without ever having to choose a trade-off. And given the finite amount of resources in the game
column18: there's very little point to returning to a finished game for more mining--eventually
column19: you will have mined all there is to mine.\n\nThis could have been solved in a number of ways. Inserting more optional high-level challenges at the beginning of the game would reward backtracking and would make the acquisition of new skills feel like more of an accomplishment. Offering more upgrade options
column20: or otherwise making stat boosting feel like more of a meaningful choice
column21: would reward playing through multiple times to experience different "builds". And a New Game+ mode that added new or more difficult enemies and additional challenges would have brought a welcome amount of replay value.\n\nThis isn't to say SteamWorld Dig is a bad game. Like I said
column22: I enjoyed it when I was playing it. But I think it's a thin game--good for a few hours of enjoyment
column23: but not anything worth returning to once you've finished it.\n\nFinal rating: 6/10"

Yet to complete the game, but I believe I have an idea of the ending just up to where I played until. Completed. General impression is pretty good. Don't know why, but I liked how you could plan the dig (awfully simple) on your way down.

PROS
1. More story as you dig deeper
I won't spoil this for you as I can only tell you that there is more stuff to get and play with as you dig deeper

2. Digging plans
You actually have to plan how you dig downwards as certain areas can regrow back. Of course, it can be solved with an infinite amount of cheap ladders. You also want areas that have water (mana) to use items such as the drill, steam punch and steam jump.

3. Teleporters
I like how you can set your save point wherever you want. I tend to put mine near the water points as you don't have water recharges close by.

CONS
1. Linear
Just dig down. It's so simple.

2. Pickaxe
Oh god... It is so tedious to dig with your pickaxe when you run out of water for the drill.

3. No tutorial
So you have to guess what the keys are or press Esc. Really ridiculous.

4. Lamps
I think there should be a use for them but I've never really needed them.

5. NPCs
Very boring. Only 5 robots? And every additional one is just a shop? You might as well put them all in one. None of them are special.

6. Enemies
Worm and robotic worm? Most of them are unique in their abilitiy but you tend to see a lot of them and you kill them all the same way... Just smack them hard...

SUGGESTION
I think there's a Japanese digger game that's similar to this. Perhaps, some competitive multiplayer might make this game even more valuable? E.g. Race to the bottom maps?

It's pretty much Terraria-lite with platforming elements and clearly defined goals. Also without any real combat system. I mean, there's kind of combat, but it's still really hard to defend yourself save for using dynamite. The upgrades you get are generally all good and I was quite happy with how mobile your main character gets by the end of the game; it plays really smoothly, definitely. No control issues at all. My one gripe is that it's really easy to get stuck to a point where you either have to die or keep digging deeper in hopes of finding the one or two teleporters in each area; true, you can bring a teleporter along yourself, but those cost orbs, which are rare and valuable and better used on other upgrades. That aside, it's a fun little exploration platformer, with some decent puzzles to boot. The story's nothing special and almost non-existent, which is really how I like it in a 2D game like this. The final boss is also pretty clever for the type of game this is and makes good use of the mechanics. All in all a delightful but short game that I'd say is probably worth full price, but wait for a sale if you're really tight on money.

This is a 2D mining game done right. The deeper you go, the harder(slower) it is to mine. Thankfully the game provides upgrades that increase the mining power of your pickaxe. Then you unlock lots of fun upgrades that build up your platforming powers. The controls are nice and behave as expected. If you're looking to get a metroid-vania fix with a bit of mining thrown in, this is about the best game I know of. Highly recommended.

My first playthrough was about 4 hours, and the second time through was just under 2 1/2. There are plenty of unlockables and secrets to keep you playing for a while longer though if you choose.

The story isn't even half bad either!

SteamWorld Dig is pretty cool. You play a robotic guy who ends up going down in his relative's mine, mining different stones or gems. In Town, there are plenty of upgrades to help your HP and Water, Pickaxe, and throughout it you will find upgrades. Going through the underground, or the mine, is pretty amazing but can be really tricky. You get even more types of things to sell, unlocking more levels and more upgrades.

Although, it is pretty easy to die if you fall, find certain enemies and have a weak pickaxe, and upgrades become REALLY needed. But the latter is actual what you're supposed to do and makes the experience much better.

I'd recommend it to people for sure. It isn't that bad of a game, and I don't feel that I'm almost done with it after getting only to the the second area underground.

Also the start of the game is extremely slow and tedious.  There isn't a whole lot of buyables and you spend way too much time digging.  As the game progresses you are able to dig faster to speed things up with a drill but the drill requires water so if you run out you have to go back to using your slow pickaxe.  And the town" really only has 3 other people (robots) in it and 1 doesn't really do anything.  The chat can be witty but really there just isn't a whole lot there.  It's a pretty short game as it is.\n\nOverall this game could be worth getting if you like sandbox puzzles but only if you can get it for a really good price.  I don't know whether to give it a thumbs up or down because I'm pretty mixed so I'll just give it a thumbs up because it still seems to be a fairy well made game and because I'm nice."

reviewText:
Steamworld dig is accourding to most people the next Must-have" Game on the 3ds and Steam but is it really true well let's begin with the story of the game.

WARNING: Spoiler alert!
The story is about a robot named Rusty coming to a town named Tumbleton when he falls into his uncle's mine. When he falls into the mine he runs into dorothy which after a brief conversation he goes to find his father when he finds out that his uncle died in the mine so you "borrow" his pickaxe to find out what he was up to. Then after a while he falls into the second section of the mine known as Old world a nuclear plant section. Then later you reach vectron a electronic generator underground where after mining a bit ou reach the final boss of the game known as the Voltbot who plans on taking over the world making voltbots the dominant species on the planet. After destroying the voltbot the mine collapses on you and you end up dying in the mine. Then the townspeople build a statue of Rusty and then the credits roll...ok I know what your thinking why didn't I mention the townspeople well because all they really do in the game is give you upgrades to your tools.

The Gameplay:
The gameplay is a mix of Metroid and Minecraft. But what do you do in steamworld dig you mine then sell your ore then go back to the mine then sell and so on. It doesn't sound like much but it's a really addicting game. Like Minecraft the main goal is to well Mine. Like Metroid the game is setup like a maze except you make the path But when you leave the cave it doesn't reset so you need to think out a move before you do it. But there is one major flaw it ends too soon just when your used to everything the game ends with the only boss in the game the voltbot also it takes around 5-6 hours to beat give or take. Yet this is also the best thing in the game too because when you beat the game it posts your score so it makes you destined to come back to beat your last score. Also there's another flaw  which are the side characters they just don't do anything but upgrade your tools.

The Verdict:
Steamworld dig is one of those masterpieces that comes around every once in a while where a game is so good you always remember the experience you had playing the game. This game is a must have game in anyone's steam library. The game is $9.99 and that is a great price so this game gets a 9.5 out of 10.

Pros:
+ Great story
+ Addictive Gameplay
+ Amazing replay value
+ Great visuals and soundtrack

Cons:
- Side characters
- Length

Definitely a very solid, enjoyable game, the gameplay a nice mix of Metroid and Terraria.  It introduces new gameplay mechanics flawlessly, right about the time when you've mastered the old ones and are looking for something new.

Don't expect this game to last too long, though - it's only about 4-5 hours of gameplay (unless you're like me and need to explore every single nook and cranny, in which case expect it to clock in at 6 hours).  Sadly, there isn't much replayability here.

My only really big complaint is the music.  Don't get me wrong, the music - what there is of it - is great.  But there's not enough.  I got pretty sick of listening to the same track over and over again while I was mining.  A little variety there is sorely missing.

7/10

SteamWorld Dig possesses a unique combination of old-school progression and mastery, and the modern spelunking style of gameplay.  As you dig deeper, you overcome challenges in order to unlock new mechanics that will enable to go further and solve new problems.  It's a tight, satisfying progression structure which fits into a relatively short, but satisfying time.\n\nPost game challenges emphasize mastery, ranking the player on the speed of completion, as well as items collected and deaths endured.  It is perhaps the most approachable game of it's kind, though gaming veterans may find it to be shallow by comparison.

Similar Games
Metroid and Sprelunky

Summary
Your uncle has left you the deed to a mine. Your goal is to find out why. You will recieve upgrades tech throughout the game by finding them in the mine as well as buying them with what you find in the mine. Delve deep and find out the mystery.

Positive
The game has very solid pacing. The atmosphere is unique and keeps you interested. The gems you dig up change as you progress. The characters may only speak in text but they are illustrated in a way where you can make it up accents by looking at them. The upgrades come in constantly which is a good thing.

Negative
The game wears thin so it is actually a good thing that it is only about 3.5 hours long. With more enemies and crazier upgrades the game could have been longer, but the real issue is the digging element itself wears thin. The story exists only to progress the game.

Conclusion
SteamWorld Dig is a solid metroidvania title that you'll enjoy until the end. That end will come rather soon, but it ends when it should. The game is from an unknown so they did a great job for there first game.

Value
I got the game in a bundle, but I'd feel solid saying you wouldn't regret paying $3.50 for it at all.

A post-apocalyptic tale (with Old West influences) of a robot who goes into a mine to continue the work of his robot uncle. You dig down, look for minerals, and unravel the mystery of how your relative disappeared. This is a simple side-scrolling platformer with some RPG elements, but a worthwhile one. It's paced nicely, the gameplay is good, the art and characters are interesting, etc.

To beat the game it requires about 3-9 hours of playtime depending on how much you explore and how many upgrades you want (personally I don't mind grinding but others may disagree). SteamWorld Dig is a bit lighthearted and casual, but it's not a yawnsome breeze to play either. You'll probably encounter a few parts here and there that are semi-challenging. Nothing serious of course, but it was nice to see some level of strategy beyond point and click anywhere to win."

This is a fun little platformer type game. Due to upgrades you get, you could say it is a metroidvania type game.

You start out with nothing and are dropped into the underground caves of a town. You a local, and are told about you uncle. Shortly after, you get you first item, a pick axe.

The game revolves around using digging devices (throughout the game you find more) to keep mining the gems under the town and fend off enimies. While there are enimies, that isn't the highlight of the game. You keep getting upgrades of your digging devices as well throughout the game.

If you die, you drop all the gems you are carring and are returned to town. You loose 50% of your gold as well, so you want to avoid this. The first time through you might find yourself digging down faster than you should. It is wise to plan ahead so you can always get back up to sell those precious gems.

While at first there might not be much stratigy, as stated above you do need to be careful just digging down and fast. Plan ahead, so you have tunnels that you can use to your advantage. Thera are consumable's you can use to help out, but I found them not very useful. I found spending my money on upgrades more worth the money.
