SteamWorld Dig is a fun little game that blends Metroidvania-esque ability progression with the platforming and money management of a mining game. You play a robot drawn to a dusty Western mining town, who discovers his miner uncle has died and left him a hole in the ground. Your goal: get to the bottom of it.

The game has a great visual style and I found the core mechanics engaging, if more than a little repetitive. It was fun for a playthrough. However, I don't think it's a home run game.

My first complaint is the story. The world of SteamWorld Dig is a neat one--a world where steam-powered robots are the dominant civilization, and some untold catastrophe has left humans trapped under the earth. But the driving plot of the game is thin to the point of being unsubstantial. Supposedly, you dig deeper in order to figure out just what your uncle was up to, but as a player, I didn't care a lick about that. I was digging just to dig.

A more compelling plot would have provided me with reason to care about my uncle and what he found. Since the mechanics of the game encourage an obsession with digging deeper, tying an insatiable urge to dig into the character of the uncle would have made him more sympathetic, and caused the story to resonate better with the gameplay. As it stands, I entirely ignored the plot" of the game
date: and I feel the lack of a story detracted from the experience.\n\nSecondly
recommended: SteamWorld Dig seems to me to have very little replay value. Your mileage may vary if you're inspired by achievements and the idea of speedrunning
hoursPlayed: but for me

votesFunny: with very few challenges requiring backtracking or use of your new abilities (as one might expect from a Metroidvania game). What's more
commentsCount: unless you are very bad at money management

Inserting more optional high-level challenges at the beginning of the game would reward backtracking and would make the acquisition of new skills feel like more of an accomplishment. Offering more upgrade options

SteamWorld Dig is a very fun 8 hours of gameplay.  There was much more story and humor than I expected going in.  I am not exactly a master of platforming (or anything reflex based) but there was something about this one that made me feel like I could wall-jump and dodge hazards all night.  The traps and puzzles were well integrated and interesting without being frustrating.  The resource gathering was engaging enough that I wanted to find all the secret areas in a way I haven't in many years.  The sound was above average and the music added to my enjoyment throughout.  I never once thought they had cut corners on the graphics or failed in achieving their artistic vision.  Even the closing credits held a fun twist.  If you are comfortable with the length, I definitely recommend this one.
Fun little metroidvania game. Dig, collect, sell, repeat. If it doesn't scratch that itch, welp maybe look elsewhere. It sure as hell did it for me!

Fun platforming and movement around the landscape. Great story, but lacks replayability. No New Game +. For a normal game, if you don't backtrack and try everything you can to get every upgrade and every piece of mineral, it'll take about 3 hours.

$9.99 USD seems too much for this game, given its lack of replayability.

But it's a great game to obtain if you get it through Humble Bundle.

I really enjoyed this game while it lasted. It's a 3-5 hour game depending on how intent you are to find every bit of treasure, but I would easily say this game is worth the asking price. The upgrades throughout the game have visible impact, which is good because half the game is getting upgrades. Not too hard, not too easy, this game is a great way to spend your Saturday.

Moderately charming little Metroidvania of sorts. Never quite manages to make you feel like you're not just going through the motions. Ends with a boss fight out of nowhere, in a game that was largey devoid of combat. Not bad.
A mix between Minecraft and Metroid. A unmatched sense of progression, discovery and exploration.

Die and you’ll have to Dark Souls your way back to your corpse to pick up everything you dropped. Also, you lose half of your pocket cash. So death really sucks, even if there’s not a lot of enemies.

Don’t dig straight down. While you won’t get stuck at the bottom of a hole, you’ll miss anything on the left or right of the hole you dug. And that’s not just precious gems to sell and fund your tool upgrades, but also steambot generators that give you new powers; like a fancy fist-launcher, or the ability to steam-jump three times as high (at the cost of water, of course).

Image & Form focused on gameplay to the exclusion of everything else, including marketing. By pouring all their talents into tactical mining and Metroideyness, they did all the marketing they needed to.

Trust us. You’ll dig it.

Read more: http://www.substance-tv.com/why-we-love-steamworld-dig/

A nice simple game for about the first hour or two, but over all is a bit of a grind and can get fairly repetative. I do like this game, just short term only. I reccomend it if it is on sale only.
Super amazing game! Don't pass it up. It look/feels like a mix between spelunky and terraria, except it has a really cool story, it's harder than it looks.

It's short, and I would never reccomend it at full price, but what little there is is done moderatley well. I feel the mining part of the game is put by the wayside in the last third of the game, but it was still enjoyable. Pick it up if it's $5 or under.

reviewText: Great.

A really good game. I haven't gotten far into the storyline yet (I just started playing today), but even though there doesn't seem to be a BIG plotline to it, it's very intriguing. It reminds me very much of a mining version of Harvest Moon. Granted, it is not exactly the same, but you inherit" your mine from your deceased uncle who apparently liked to work with a whole bunch of random contraptions that give you boosts and such."

I played through SteamWorld Dig on my 3DS first, and after about an hour with the PC version I can safely report that it holds up even on a bigger screen and a more powerful machine.

It is an enjoyable Metroidvania style game about exploring randomly generated mines in search of new special powers and some sweet minerals. Because of its portable roots the game encourages (or rather forces you into) short mining sessions by giving you a limited amount of lantern time and a very small inventory space for minerals. After you return to the surface you can sell your minerals for some gold, and then buy consumable items or permanent upgrades for your HP or lantern or for the various special powers you come across while mining.

The game is in no ways very deep, but it is very easy to get hooked in the simple but rewarding mining. The mixture of scifi/western on the art also makes the game fun and unique. It can also get quite atmospheric on the dimly lit mines which have great ambient background music and changing art assets when you get deeper. SteamWorld Dig comes highly recommended.
Fun, not too long, has ending.
Addiction Simulator 2013

I think they could have done more with this game. I beat it in less than 5 hours of total gameplay and only died 12 times. I enjoyed digging around and all, and some of the puzzles were interesting but it could have gone more in depth (no pun intended, well maybe a little). The mines are all attached in a downward direction and you are collecting gems and then cashing them up to level up your digging, health, stamina (steam processing). The upgrades just come really fast and before you know it the whole game is over. You aren't really exploring and finding anything special, just uncovering more of the same in whatever section you are in. The difficulty scales with the upgrades you get, so it never gets too hard, but it wasn't that difficult.\n\nOverall I would say it is worth it if you find it on sale or in a bundle.

I got this game as part of the Humble Bundle 12, and it was totally worth it. Although I beat the game in a total of 3 hours game time, there's so much more to do than just the main story. I still had quite a few upgrades to buy and places to explore. The atmosphere, story, and artwork are all absolutely fantastic. I can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Fun game - 100% completed in around 5 hours (Collected all / discovered all).

The game is basicaly about digging minerals for cash -> trading cash for upgrades and digging deeper into unknown. Along the way you meet brainless monsters that prolong your stay underground before restocking in town.

If you expect it to be action/spelunky type game - it's not. It's fun but nothing really special. There are many other titles better then this. Although it's fun and casual + as for me for one-walkthrough (~5 hours gameplay)

Bought it at the ongoing HumbleBundle sale. Oh boy, just wanted to have a try this night, ended up goin' diggin for about three hours. So far it's an addictive making experience. The upgrade for your character are coming in just perfect to keep you motivated all the time. And the mixture between Jump n Run and diggin the ♥♥♥♥ out of the levels is just awesome. In the trailer the diggin seems a bit boring but its extremly well set up in the game environment so its a very exciting experience and you will find yourself in the loop of mining and upgrading in no time. The level design just makes fun and the graphics are very good aswell and a nice change compared to the famous 8-bit looks these days - which i like but after the 10th game its nice to have some variety. And there are jewels and drills, and super-burning-fists, upgrades, funky characters. You really should try it out as soon as you can!
Great gameplay, graphics, sound, just wish it was a little longer. I am not a big fan of expansions but I would buy an expansion for this game.

SteamWorld Dig is a nice 2D mining adventure game where the goal is to dig, collect gems and sell them so you can buy upgrades to help you dig further down into the mine. That simple sentence sums up the game but there are enough monsters and traps as you head down the mine to make the game very engaging the whole way through.\n\n8.5/10

Great game!

Do you like Metroid but only have Steam? Are you a sorry excuse of a misogynistic human being? Then play SteamWorld Dig! It's Metroid on a mining theme and everyone is a robot and therefore genderless.

The upgrade system is very cleverly balanced to keep you striving for that next bit of loot just enough to not seem tedious or drawn out, some players may feel themselves compelled to complete the game in one setting ( I did it in two 2 hour sittings) One major drawback is that the end boss is extremely weak sauce and I didn't notice any new game + type mode.\n9/10

Somewhat short but still a fun game to play. I really enjoyed going through each level and searching for hidden rooms and minerals. plays well, runs well, overall 8/10. it's a bit short and you have other games along the same vein such as terreria that are longer and have more meat on em. That is not to say that steam world dig is too short or bad, but it could be better.

reviewText: Dig every single penny out at last for a $3000 item.

This game reminds me of both Dig Dug and Metroid in a way. On the dig dug side you dig linear tunnels and face monsters+environmental hazards while on the Metroid side more so you discover new power up/abilities that make it easier to navigate and explore.\n\nIts short but well worth the experience.

A great game! B+

I have to admit I haven't banked enough hours on the PC version of this game, but I have it on 3DS as well and play the heck out of it.

The story is VERY basic, graphics are nice and smooth, gameplay is simple and addicting. It's the type of game you can come back and play several times, and that's helped by the layout being random every time you play. That alone right there is a great plus to an already nice time you'll have playing. You'll just want to keep digging down looking for as much ore as you can before reaching the final area.

My only problems are this... the game is plenty short. You can blow through it really fast if you don't take your time to savor it. Speed running need not apply here. Also, there's only 1 boss and it's at the ending, and that boss isn't very challenging. These 2 things are greatly helped by the random layouts, and the fact that the digging in itself is a bit of a challenge. You'll find yourself wanting to dig patterns so you'll be able to even escape if something goes wrong down there. And that's not as easy as you may think. It's almost like a puzzle.

So yes it's a great game everyone should have in their collection.
The length? yeah a bit disappointing. But I bet you'll be saying to yourself One more time!""

My two SteamWorld Digs: Addicting, well designed game, with western-robot-steam-punk-RPG elements that are pretty cool. If we add Spaghetti Western-like music, a story that is surely essential, but still enjoyable, and an Half-Life 3 easter egg gag, we obtain a game that is a must buy.  (Y)

Solid game. Those OCD types who have to clear EVERYTHING will be happy with this one and, frankly, will find it more satisfactory a purchase than those who make a sprint of it. If you're looking to kill a day with some well-rendered MetroidVania stuff, this is a decent choice. It's not as well-rounded, meaty or challenging as Guacamelee (which is fantastic), but it's worth a few hours and a few bucks. 7/10
short but fun.

A reasonably fun digging game, although a game where you spend 97% of you time digging with no real purpose can feel kind of dull. The actual digging part resembles Terraria, although instead of the different varieties of ore found in Terraria, Steamworld Dig just has gem nodes that give you junk to exchange for gold. Unlike Terraria, the stuff you gather while digging doesn't have any real use. You just trade it for gold and use that gold to upgrade your digging capabilities. So that you can dig faster, get more gold, and use it to buy more upgrades. Perhaps this is a deep meditation on the pointlessness of consumerism. Or maybe its just kinda dull gameplay.

Towards the end of the game, there are caves that feature something resembling puzzles, although none of those puzzles are particularly puzzling. They still make for a nice break from the previous ~4 hours of largely uninterrupted digging.

Aside the from the general tedium of the gameplay, my major complaint is the death penalty. You lose half the gold you're carrying every time you die. And because there are only a limited number of gem nodes, you can only get so much gold during the game. If you die more than a few times, you will not be able to afford all the upgrades. This ultimately doesn't really matter, since the upgrades just make you dig faster or die less. But not being able to get everything is frustrating.

The story is mostly non-existent, with a random conclusion thrown in at the very end. The narrative certainly won't keep you going if you find the gameplay dull.

Overall, I mostly enjoyed Steamworld Dig even with all my complaints. This is probably just because I tend to enjoy tedium in games if it comes along with a sense of progress. If you enjoyed the mining aspects of Terreria, you may like this game. If you like grinding in JRPGs just to make your characters' numbers bigger, you may like this game. However, if you want exciting action or a compelling story, Steamworld Dig is not for you.

I would give Steamworld Dig a 6.5/10 and recommend it only if you like digging.

I'm sincerely baffled by all the positive reviews this game has... It almost feels like people didn't even test the game at all.

If you want a fun Metroidvania, just play Unepic.
If you want a fun rogue-like, play Spelunky.
If you want a fun mining game, play Terraria (or even Minecraft)

Thumbs up for the graphics though, I gotta admit the 2D steampunk atmosphere is very appealing visually.

+ Visuals

Final note: 3/10

Do not let my short time with this version mislead you; whereas, I have destroyed the 3DS version of this game and found myself surprisingly hooked for hours.  I was pleasantly surprised to notice this on sale today, and purchased it immediately - it's that good.  After only 15 minute on the Steam/PC version, rest assured, the transition is everything it should be.  Here's an actual review of the game itself.  Last, I apologize now for spelling, grammatical, or contextual errors, i.e., I am typing quickly in a dark room~\n\nThis game is fresh, imaginitive, visually stylish, and is easy to pickup, but requires elements of strategy as you dig and rewards you with progress often.  It delivers a perfect balance; whereas, it is far from super easy, though never hits impossibile or the bang your head against the wall to end it all 'frustration rage' (we've all seen this, be it controllers, walls, friends, etc).  You start casually, but there are no long drawn out tutorials, cut scenses, or credits.  Shorrtly after hitting the start button, you are playing - a feature that is more uncommon than is often noted.  Its apparent almost immediately that the game possesses visually asthetic fluidity.   As you continue to explore, the pacing set by the game is consistently maitained and develops respective to the depths you traverse, and keeps you balanced by means of progressive upgrades, powerups, the twon's growth, purchasable items, and increased value of the loot you find. This game constantly rewards you and creates the sense of wanting to play just a bit longer.  I found myself setting aside some of lifes responaibilities simply because I enjoyed the time I spent playing, e.g., foolhardily making the wife wait longer than any wife prefers to wait...multiple times (Protip: AVOID this mistake).  Additionally, the balance feels very natural and honestly has a rare bit of brillance that you never really think about, probably because it does play so well.  The time you spend jmping through the air, punching, digging, upgrading your items, treking back to town, while thinking about how youre going to get all the way back to the pipe/teleporter as you make some questionable wall jumps never really got old; rather, it did feel as though you accomplished and understand the game more.  As the game tosses new dynamics this feeling continued to evolve... and I found myself enjoying it as I evolved as a player.  Despite the hollistic theme of digging, digging, digging, the gameplay never really got old.  It all comes together in a package that delivers an experience that really ends up complimeting the multiple componets of its own gameplay; therfore, bringing itself together delivering syle, balance, exploration, while provinding a (gamer's) sense of accomplishment, excitment, and fun -> a feeling often associated with video games; however, is all too often replaced with a sense of obligation to finish simply becasue we started or have put so much into it.  This gam never created a sense of obligation, and if your a gamer you know the feeling I am referring to.  This game transcends that dynamic and sccomplishes the ever more difficult task of creating the fundemtntial elements of enjoyment.  This game is appropriate for gamers of all ages, styles, and skill level(s).  The constant rewards will develop younger players, yet can offer old school gamers (the one's who grew up on arcades/atari/nes/collecovison) an experience that is a often more difficult to find in a game.  Buy it.  You will literally find yourself digging in~
This game kicks ♥♥♥. dont over spend on teleports

Really enjoyable so far, and while I had never heard of the game prior to news of it first breaking on game sites about its port over to PC, I can absolutely see why this garnered so much attention and love from review sites for the DS.  Extremely simple and very entertaining
the game is really fun if you want to do a quickie game here and there. I recommend this game to casual and hard core gamers alike.

Take the feature of digging and exploring a world below from games like Minecraft, Terraria etc. and make a Robot Western Mining Singleplayer Adventure out of it and you have SteamWorld Dig. Adding this to the top10 Indies of the year as you won´t find a lot of games who take up something that has been done already and are still able to make it interesting again.
Worth buying! Funny game , i don't know why i didn't find it earlier.

This game was good, but short. The stoyline lasted about 4hrs for me, but I did not stick around farm all the upgrades. The level designs are nice and the puzzles are interesting but not too difficult. I was expecting more of a sandbox, but was still satisfied overall. I recommend a controller for this title.
Det är bra men lite för kort.
If you played Motherlode, you'll like this. It's got the same basic structure, you dig down, collect stuff, sell it, buy upgrades, etc.\nIdk, I suck at reviews, but I really liked it.
Very well thought out miner game. Instead of the need to unlock a pickaxe to venture deeper, it takes more hits to mine on deeper levels. SteamWorld Dig is a steampunk game with great graphics.
This is one of those great games that showes evolution for platformers. Addictive.

This game is awesome. I played it for 3DS and it was awesome. This is just as amazing. I could not recommend this game more. It's a little short, but if you can get it on sale I would HIGHLY recommend it. It's amazing. I can not wait for the sequel.
2 hour gameplay.
I thought this would be just another game that I pick up because numerous people had talked about it, but it really is amazing, and I can see myself playing this for many hours to come.
Awesome game. Wish it were longer, and nothing other bad I can say about it.
SteamWorld Dig for $2.49. Yes please.\nHell, I paid $7.49 for it back in December, and I believe it deserves even more than that.\nExtremely addictive and fun! Killed a good 10-12 hours on this.
I'm really digging this game

This game is everything you want in a platforming, mining, wtfpwning game. Only about 6 hours worth of gameplay... but it's the kind of 6 hours you do all at once without realizing it. Highly recommend.
Great time burner yet it has a level of replayability and fun that would keep me going for hours on end.
A fun little gem but a bit too short for its price I feel.

This game's really fun, great soundtrack, great sense of progression with unlocking new power ups to find new things in old areas. It's a mix of metroid, terraria, and say, mario. It's kinda of a platformer, with mega man style wall jumps, which is really cool.\nBUY THIS GAME.

Really makes you feel like you're playing an oldschool title with all the added action and fun newer titles have brought the past few years. Like a combination of metroid and terraria and spelunky if you like digging and exploring while getting power ups on the way this is a great game to pick up
Kept me playing through to the end. Short and sweet exploration game with lots of upgrades to purchase and new abilities to learn.
Other than the ending, I don't think there's much not to like in this game.

Interesting combination of puzzler and platformer/adventurer (mostly the latter), with very well done pacing. New upgrades and enemies / mechanics are introduced at a good rate, and it hasn't stagnated so far.
It is a all around good digging game.

Fun enough - took me about 7 hours, which ended up being a little over $1 a hour with the sale price.

Not a whole lot of depth or story, but what can really be expected of a glitzed up flash game? Did a good job for what it is.

7.5/10
Tons of fun! A good puzzleish-platformer game with digging! Fun upgrades keep the game fresh as you go through.

The first time coming into his game, I did not know what to think. Honestly, the look of the game was amazing graphics wise but wasn't sure if this game would be something I could get into. I did. Seriously cannot stop playing it. I'm not much of a gamer, as a single dad I rarly get time to myself..I started playing this game at night before bed. it's incredibly addicting in every single way possible. in all honesty I give it a 10/10.

This game is amazing. The digging and upgrading is fun and feel fufilling while the story of a pretty cool world is slowly revealed to you through npcs. Its also on the perfect level of difficulty were its not activly hard but if you dont pay attention you will die. I shouldnt have to mention that this game is fun to look at, no scratch that, its addicting. My only gripe is the controls are abut odd but its fine after the first 10 or so minutes. Buy it at full price so we can see more wonderful games come from this studio!

SteamWorld Dig is a very fun 8 hours of gameplay.  There was much more story and humor than I expected going in.  I am not exactly a master of platforming (or anything reflex based) but there was something about this one that made me feel like I could wall-jump and dodge hazards all night.  The traps and puzzles were well integrated and interesting without being frustrating.  The resource gathering was engaging enough that I wanted to find all the secret areas in a way I haven't in many years.  The sound was above average and the music added to my enjoyment throughout.  I never once thought they had cut corners on the graphics or failed in achieving their artistic vision.  Even the closing credits held a fun twist.  If you are comfortable with the length, I definitely recommend this one.
Fun little metroidvania game. Dig, collect, sell, repeat. If it doesn't scratch that itch, welp maybe look elsewhere. It sure as hell did it for me!

Fun platforming and movement around the landscape. Great story, but lacks replayability. No New Game +. For a normal game, if you don't backtrack and try everything you can to get every upgrade and every piece of mineral, it'll take about 3 hours.

$9.99 USD seems too much for this game, given its lack of replayability.

But it's a great game to obtain if you get it through Humble Bundle.

I really enjoyed this game while it lasted. It's a 3-5 hour game depending on how intent you are to find every bit of treasure, but I would easily say this game is worth the asking price. The upgrades throughout the game have visible impact, which is good because half the game is getting upgrades. Not too hard, not too easy, this game is a great way to spend your Saturday.

Moderately charming little Metroidvania of sorts. Never quite manages to make you feel like you're not just going through the motions. Ends with a boss fight out of nowhere, in a game that was largey devoid of combat. Not bad.
I recomend this game to anyone who loves a minecraft rpg-ish western suvival game.

It's a modern graphics version of the old Dig Dug or Motherload games.

As usual, dig down, go back up, buy upgrades to dig further down and move around better. The bottom layer is usually a hell layer with the big boss, which is usually your mentor or father or some other kind of person gone bad.

It doesn't add anything new other than graphics and a cool soundtrack and a cool western robot setting. If you've seen Futurama, Bender, those types of robots.

Remember that it is a mobile game ported to PC so it is very short.

My total hours probably say something around 4 hours... that's how long it takes to beat.

You don't actually do all that much mining. You just dig down, make sure to get a few ores on the way and that's it. It has a slight puzzle aspect to it because you can't mine diagonally, you can't mine while hanging from a ceiling etc. You can only mine up 1 block, left, right and down. So if you don't play smart, you can get stuck. Upgrades aleviate this but not entirely.

I got it in a bundle, so paid maybe 1 buck for it.

The graphics and themes and sounds are more polished than other games in its genre so I'd say it's worth a few bucks.

There's many flash games out there for free, with the same gameplay.

Overall is a original well executed game.
Fun but easy. Relatively short and lacking challenges and depth.
Get it on sales and you will have some fun.

Looking forward the second (or third) part. By that time the game will have much more to offer.

This one took me by surprise. Rather than spoil too much about it, I'll just say that if you enjoy creating your own physical path through a game world while being immersed in an interesting and quite unexpected story, then this is a game you'd also enjoy.

I think the only real issue I had with this game was that it was too short. I wished it was longer. Only six hours of gameplay. However, during that six hours it was awesome. This game brings me back 10 years to a flash game that was really similar.

Somewhat short but still a fun game to play. I really enjoyed going through each level and searching for hidden rooms and minerals. plays well, runs well, overall 8/10. it's a bit short and you have other games along the same vein such as terreria that are longer and have more meat on em. That is not to say that steam world dig is too short or bad, but it could be better.
Great game, highly recommended!

Great little Metroidvania meets Terraria type game.

pros:
Fun to upgrade your bot
Satisfying to bring back a big loot of ores.
Controls feel good
Deaths are your fault

Cons:
Perhaps just a tad linear as far as exploring goes, you just go deeper.

Would definately reccomend it!
This is the best game so far in this genre. Love it.

This is a wonderful little game that you can play for 5 minutes or 5 hours.\n\nIt is Dig Dug plus Minecraft and it is fun, accessible and is something I turn to when I stare at my game list and don't want to commit" to playing a new game."

For its price this game gives some solid 3 to 4 hours of entertainment.

Fun to play, easy to learn.

Only gripe, some abilities come too late, and are only used for the last 20 minutes of the game.


Would love to see an expansion pack for more exploring.

Amazing game !
Very addictive, very funny.
It's remind me Metroid, a very beautiful memory of old game.
But i think it's a little short.
A must have for any fans of Terraria, Metroid-Vania, and/or westerns
Good game for the price, this is a solid metroidvania, with some mining elements.  It's not at all procedural, though.

The Short:
+ Exellent Gameplay
+ Rewarding Upgrade System
+ Solid Controls
+ Vivid, Beautiful Graphics
- Short (around 3 hours)
Just like motherload

I found this game very reminicient of some of the different mining flash games you see online.  Dig deeper into the earth, find more valuable things as you do, and bring them back to the surface to sell so you can upgrade your digger.  This game changes things a bit by having a bit of a story and more interactions with some puzzle elements and enemies, which helped it from feeling too repetitive during its short runtime.  Game only took 5 hours or so to finish, so good for a quick fix if you can pick it up on sale.
game is great..just really short. as is, i recommend it, but if they release some DLC for it to lenghten the experience it will go from great to amazing :)
Really fun and addictive game. Looks and plays great (with a controller. Havn´t played with kb)
Pretty good game. I liked it I mean wasn't as long as I had expected it to be but overall definitely worth the playthrough.

Classic Game. Got a lot of hate for being similar to other games but to be honest it is its own game and is really like nothing else ive ever played. the graphics are colorful and HD and the gameplay is addictive. You wont want to stop playing and you will want to get all the acheivements. Overall a great game and i would recommend it to anyone.

Just finished this one up and really had a lot of fun. But then again I am very patient. For a good portion of this game after a few accomplishments earlier in game play you'll find yourself a little confused. After digging and digging and more digging I started wondering if I was missing something or even going in the right direction. There isn't much indication of where you are in your game play which is fine but you don't find yourself finding an exact direction(besides down) to follow. Not to spoil but I believe the ending was left wide open for an inevitable sequel which I will be more than happy to play and look forward to more defined levels" and maybe the addition of more Bosses. The final battle for me was really satisfying because of it's nastalga boss battle feel and I really wished I had more of that throughout the game. Maybe even a Completion bar would be nice to have to know whether or not it would be worth the time and effort to go out Mining and have the satisfaction of knowing that every nook
date: cranny and stone has been turned for that 100% completion.\nsolid 3.5/5 for me"
hoursPlayed: true

reviewText:
Get it on sale and enjoy the experience.
I had no personal compulsion to replay it to get all the extra acchievements.

Gameplay was good enough to keep me going over a weekend.
Controls were suprisingly responsive.
Enough enemy variety to keep things going until the end.
Platforming/mining was typical of the genre.
New abilities were gateways to progression.
Upgrades were by the numbers.
Visuals/style suited the setting/game.
Plot was basic.
8.5/10 not much replay value, but it was a great game!

Fantastic game! This is what I want when buying a mining platformer. It is short but the environments are interesting and some parts are challenging. Plus, I can easily see the potential for more levels down the line. Kind of like Megaman, but with less backtracking; the potential is there to build that kind of scope into this game.

SteamWorld Dig is a fantastic little game.  It is very short, but to be honest it feels about right length wise.  Had I bought it full price it would still have been worth it for the enjoyment it gave me.  However, at 50% off on sale it was an absolute steal.
This is a wonderful mix of MetroidVania style exploration, Megaman X upgrades, and crafting!  Seriously fun!

A very fun game, but very short.

It took me little over 6 hours to complete the game (and nearly all the achievements).
I feel like the game could benefit greatly from more challenges hidden throughout the world, and even New Game+.
While it was a very short experience, I enjoyed every second of it.

FUN.  It's like a mashup of Torchlight style dungeon-crawlers and mining games (Terraria/Starbound) with some platforming thrown in for kicks.  Rather more lightweight than those examples as it wants to be more of a jack-of-all-trades, master-of-none sort of game but totally worth it when it's on sale.  I would be all over a slightly more complex sequel.
A well-made adventure game. The western Steampunk-ish feel to it is a really nice touch

This game is surprisingly good, and also a relatively good challenge, which is something rare in the gaming industry now days. When I picked it up I was afraid it will be just another boring title, but so far I'm loving it and I've decided to do a full playthrough of it on my YT channel.

Personally I recommend it for anyone that likes this genre, check it out at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SEGUkyWO4MU

Thumbs up!
Pretty fun gaem its kinda a mix of metroid and digging to make your own lvls. I likes it and its on sale for $5 so worth it
SteamWorld Dig is not a very long game but it's pretty fun. If you like Terraria or any of the other digging games, you'll enjoy this
Such a great 2D platform mining game with great visuals and sound

It may have only lasted 5 hours, but it was 5 hours well spent! The gameplay is a mix of Terraria and Metroid and it works wonderfully! It's so unique in its art style and soundtrack too! Honestly Rusty is my Hero. I hope they make a sequel some day soon!

This is probablly one of the best games I have ever played!\nThe art style and the animations are amazing! I really hope they add packets where we can just install and we can continue our jeorney! :) Great game!
Reminds me of Dig Dug!

I have always loved the mining genre of games and this one is close to perfect. I just wish there were more to do. WIth updates and more content, I would rate this game 5 stars, but as it stands now...4 stars.

If you like Terraria, you'll love this --\n\nThis basically removes terraria's building. Enhances the mining, and adds a plot. Such a fun game, the boss at the end will have you sitting there for hours. Very fun single player game to open when you have 1-2 hours to spare. Worth every penny.
Simple and good fun ! 5H for the first playthrough. Non random levels for a change and gathering precious stones is satisfying in itself.

A solid game about digging, jumping, and selling gems with charming robotic shanty town people. Took me a touch over 6hrs to beat the game, with a bit of rushing at the end. Make sure you have a controller! Worth picking up (especially at $5) but would not spend more than $1/hr on this, as there is little to no reason to play it more than once, unless you <3 achievements.
